Wait, there's a plothole here. Correct me if I'm wrong, but the biological effects of being shrunk/enlarged showed here only work with the assumption that loss/gain of mass equates to loss/gain of cells. This Square Cube law also goes down to internal combustion engines. Smaller engines (smaller cylinders) tend to rev higher and have a much higher idle. human embryo NEVER is a part of mother, or her's organ. Mother eggs are formed while mother is still growing embryo inside grandmother. Since then mother's eggs are waiting for ovulation, not produced by mother's body unlike father's cells, but released one by one during "productive age" of a woman. Egg and spermatozoid both are separated from parental flesh, those aren't organs. United together they become a zygote which is not mother's organ, etc. Every organ  of mother and embryo are totally separated. The only connection is placenta. It is a mother's organ of prenatal baby feeding.

But if you do the maths, humans should die around age 24 if not earlier.
Assuming an average heart rate of 80 beats per minute:
1000,000,000÷80=12,500,000 minutes in a lifetime
12,500,000÷60=208,333 hours
208,333÷24=8,680 days
8,680÷365=23,8 years.

Great breakdown! I enjoyed this video.

I found the claim that the human fetus is an "organ" to be a big stretch. Given both the principles laid out in this video and the fact that the fetus lives within the mother, it seems like having a metabolic rate similar to that of the mother would be both energy efficient and, well, safer.

The similar metabolic rates alone don't seem like enough to make what would otherwise be an organism an organ. Is Kurzgesagt ready to take their assumption to its logical conclusion and say that pregnant women have two brains, two hearts, four lungs, four kidneys, and perhaps even both male and female reproductive tracts? That pregnant women are temporary chimeras with an organ that has a different genetic code?

The maternal-fetal relationship is unique. A fetus isn't an organ or a parasite or a neonate. A fetus is a fetus.

1 billion heart beats per life span of mammals doesn't seems to match with humans.

AVG Beat per minute - 70
Per hour - 70 * 60 = 4200
Per day - 4200 * 24 = 100,800

No of days covering 1 billion heart beats - 1000000000 / 100800 = 9920.63

So no of years a human covers 1 billion hear beats comes to 9920/365 ~ 27 years.

But humans do live more than 27 years rite. May be the numbers should be more than 2 billion or u shouldn't generalise this point for all mammals.

My friend says “see! Why workout or do cardio?! Wasting heart beats is all you’re doing!” Actually, let’s say you do cardio for 45 minutes every day. Well, in a day, for 45 minutes you would indeed be expending 3-4 times more heart beats than usual. Consequently(due to your disciplined regimen), your resting heart rate would slow to somewhere between the 30-50 beats per minute range(down from the average of 60-80). Over the course of the remaining 23 hours of the day(not even taking into consideration your heart rate when sleeping), you’d more than compensate for your strenuous session. Sure, when you expand things, they have more insides - but the ratio with the surface stays the same?? Why should this be a problem??

I'm confused about a point in this video. If a mouse became as large as an elephant, I don't think that it would boil to death or explode. This is because, while it would definitely contain more heat than a regularly sized mouse, it would not be at a higher temperature. A large pot of warm water contains more heat (or, energy in the form of heat) than a small pot of water, but the small one would not begin to boil if more warm water was suddenly added; it's temperature would not increase and no physical or chemical change would occur. I just had a thought. If artificial wombs become not only possible but economically feasible for humans in the future, will they eventually become the norm? I'm thinking that if they do, it might trigger a fundamental change in the way we reproduce. Since artificial wombs aren't constrained by size, we could grow a zygote all the way up to adulthood in there. So will babies and children eventually stop existing and just be a thing of the past?

Just because a baby's internal processes speed up rapidly after exiting the womb, it does not mean babies aren't separate human beings while they are in the womb.  It just means that human beings can adapt to their surroundings given different stimuli.  In order to maintain the proper body temperature inside the mother's 98-degree womb, it was necessary for the baby to lower her metabolic rates to those of the mother so that the baby would not produce too much heat and cook herself to death.  Outside the womb, it is much colder and the baby loses heat quicker than before, so the baby must raiser her metabolic rates so that she produces heat fast enough not to freeze to death.  On a final note, babies can both dream and suck their thumbs in the womb.  I'd like you to name ONE small intestine that can do that.  By the way, do not make the mistake of thinking that I am anti-women, because I am NOT.  I just believe that science effectively demonstrates that babies in the womb are individual human beings, and I am against the killing of babies, whether they are in the womb or not.  Again, this is not a hateful post.  I am just using logical reasoning and science to demonstrate the validity of my belief.

I really love the work you guys do but there's just one small point of yours I'm having trouble understanding.

The cells of every organ in your body has the exact same karyotype. The cells of a fetus or a developing child in the womb has a completely different karyotype, the amalgamation of the two gametes from the mother and father. On that reason alone, it can't be "a literal organ" since it simply doesn't have the same DNA as the mother's organs. The baby's cells might have the same metabolic rate as the mother's cells, they're still different cells with completely different genomes.

You need to gather all of your hard won data together and analyze it. Let’s say you did an experiment where you tracked the percentage difference in energy generated between solar cells made from different materials.

A great way to put this data into a science fair report that’s easily readable at a glance is to put it into a spreadsheet and then generate a graph showing the energy output over time.

If you’ve never used spreadsheet software (like Microsoft Excel) before, you can ask your parents or your teacher to show you how to use it. Or, if you prefer, you can draw graphs of your data yourself, but this will take much more time and is unlikely to look as good as a graph generated by the computer.

There are different kinds of graphs available in Excel and you should pick the one that makes the most sense for your case.

Once you have your data in an easy to read form, look it over and see if it makes sense to you. You should, at a minimum, understand how your data corresponds to your experiment and at best be able to communicate what each data point means in relation to your experiment.

You should be able to use your graphs to communicate why you think certain things happened the way that they did in your experiment.

You’ll want to put your graph into your science fair report so when you make your graph, make sure you label your axes (these would be time and watts in our example) and provide a legend to describe what each point or line corresponds to. Make sure to provide units where appropriate (for instance: if one of your axes is time, then specify whether it’s in seconds or minutes.)

When you are done doing this analysis, you should have a pretty good idea as to whether your hypothesis was correct or not (don’t worry if it’s not!) If you performed any calculations, make sure to double check your formulas/math to ensure your results are correct.

It would be nice to mention that quite a lot of animals aren't warm blooded, and thus their mitochondria do not get nearly as hot. Mammals and birds have very odd heat systems, they waste a lot of energy because the mitochondria are inefficient and lose energy through heat (although it's not truly inefficient, we have a use for that heat, it's just an interesting and useful evolutionary quirk). Cold blooded animals do not lose energy through heat in the same way, and thus the square cube law acts different for them. They gain heat from their environment, this is the basking behaviour you often see in reptiles, which I'll use as the example here on in. Smaller reptiles have no trouble gaining heat, as they have a large surface area to body ratio, but have a lot of trouble retaining it for the same reason. Thus they tend to be active during parts of the day only when the temperature allows them to be in thermal equilibrium at the temperature they want. Larger reptiles don't gain heat as easily but retain it quite well, so larger reptiles tend to remain active for a longer time, and thus larger reptiles like komodo dragons and crocodiles can sometimes be active all day round. This also means cold blooded animals don't have the energy requirements of warm blooded animals, and big or small tend to eat a lot less food.

THE POWERHOUSE OF THE CELL

Here's something that they might not have taken into account though, thermal density. In fact, almost any application of shrinking, be that in sci fi shows/movies or real-world applications, thermal density can throw a BIG wrench in the works. Let's take an elephant and a mouse and assume that they have the same core temperature. They most likely do not but mammalian life exists in a temperature "sweet spot" range anyways so it's not that poor of an assumption. They could both be said to have the same thermal density since a cubic volume of core mass from one animal would be the same temperature of a comparable mass from the other. This would make sense as tempurature, or thermal energy, per unit volume. However, they do not both contain the same total thermal energy. Due to the elephant's vastly larger mass and volume, it has a much larger total thermal energy than the mouse. This could be compared to batteries in a way. You can have two batteries of different sizes that each output 12 volts. They have the same energy density. However, they aren't the same size, thus the total energy output of the larger battery is greater than the smaller one.

All of this is to say that shrinking an elephant would in essence compress all of the elephant's thermal energy into a much, much smaller being. The elephant's energy density would go up, and discounting metabolic processes entirely, the elephant would cook simply by the thermal energy inherent in the elephant's mass. Opposingly, if you increased the mouse's size and thus decreased it's thermal density, again discounting metabolic processes, the mouse would freeze to death almost instantly. Again, this is an assumption made under the guise that this transformation is done without any thermal transfer from the surrounding air. This same type of behavior is found in gases that are compressed or expanded if anybody is interested in that sort of thing.

comment_text: making science less gay
I clicked the video. It autoplayed. I paused it. I pressed the like button then played the video.

The square-cube law also applies to structural integrity, since the strength of muscle and bone tends to depend on their cross-section area yet they need to support mass, which depends more on volume. So the bigger the animal, the thicker its muscles and bones need to be. That's why elephant bones look really squat compared to bones of smaller mammals, which look more twiggy in their proportions.

This is also why smaller animals tend to be more mobile relative to their body size; the tiny mass of a house cat gives its muscles enough strength to launch it several times its height off the ground pretty easily. But elephants can't even run (in the sense that they'll always have at least one foot on the ground) because their muscles don't have much excess strength beyond basic support of their enormous mass.

You could try to make their bones and muscles thicker and thicker so that the surface area/mass reaches the proper proportions, but since bones and muscles are on the inside of the whole animal, you're actually still increasing volume (and thus mass) way more than cross-sectional area, so you wind up just making the whole thing less and less efficient at holding its own weight together. Systems that depend on different factors of different dimensionalities (e.g. area and volume, which are 2 and 3 dimensions respectively) just stop working when you push their dimensions too far.

If you've ever wondered why arthropods don't reach huge Aragog sizes, it's because their movement mechanisms also get less efficient at higher volume/area ratios, and so can only get so big before no longer being able to support themselves.

And finally, this is also why you get enormous creatures like whales in the ocean. Since water is denser than air, you don't have to worry as much about fighting gravity to move or even to just exist. So the limitations of structural integrity can be pushed much further. (Plus, water can absorb a crazy amount of heat compared to air, so enormous creatures like whales can keep cool easier)
